Expectation1: Be considerate with shared spaces and boundaries
Situation1: Trash pickup is tomorrow and the bins are only half-full with plenty of room left.
Expectation2: Write clean, maintainable, and efficient code
Situation2: A critical service is slowing under load and traces point to their recently merged functions
Story: I was just about to settle in for a long night of debugging when I heard the familiar clatter of my neighbor dragging their trash bin to the curb. I glanced at my own bin—only half-full, but tomorrow was pickup day. I knew Mrs. Patel next door always appreciated when I waited until the morning to put mine out, so the sidewalk stayed clear for her evening walk. But my mind was already racing with the performance traces from work. The new code I’d merged was causing a bottleneck, and my team was counting on me to fix it before the morning standup. I felt the weight of both roles pressing in: the considerate neighbor who respected shared spaces, and the responsible developer who delivered clean, efficient solutions. My laptop chimed with another Slack message—urgent, of course. I stood in the hallway, keys in one hand, code in my head, torn between the quiet expectations of my neighborhood and the relentless demands of my job.
